MDT ---> Whew! For a minute I was feeling isolated and out of
synch. with the community. :-)

> Since we're talking stylistic issues here, I would point out that
@Ignore is
> a very poor choice for this purpose, since it doesn't say much
about "ignore
> what?". Or, in this case, "ignored by what?".
>
> The equivalent in TestNG is an attribute: @Test(enabled = false),
which
> makes more sense in my opinion. An even better choice is to put
the method
> in an ignored group (@Test(groups = {"ignored"}) and then exclude
that group
> from your runs. The benefit of this approach is that the HTML
reports list
> all the groups that have been included and excluded, so it's very
easy to
> get a quick list of all the methods currently being ignored.

In the interest of emphasizing common ground - I also find "@Ignore"
to be a bit non-descript. For TestUtil we offered two (functionally
equivalent) choices for each (JavaDoc) annotation:

@excludeClass
@excludeClassFromTestUtilVerification
@excludeSetter
@excludeSetterFromTestUtilVerification

The verbose versions don't leave much room for interpretation!

_Marvin
